Apr 25, 2023

Maker's marks for King's Day

It‚Äôs late in the morning and I‚Äôm on my way to Gerimedica, the company‚Äôs I‚Äôm excited to be joining in May, which is next week already. I‚Äôm on my bike listening to an American podcast about the history of Dutch anarchist cycling culture.1 The scene could only be more Dutch if I had a frying pan with bitterballen on the back of my bike.

The commute is wonderful: it takes me from the East side of Amsterdam via De Pijp and Vondelpark to perhaps the most beautiful building I‚Äôve ever had the privilege of calling my office. I cross the river Amstel, enjoy the sun, and marvel at the preparations people have been making.

In two days, King‚Äôs Day is upon us. It‚Äôs always a big event in the country, and specifically in Amsterdam, and this year it‚Äôs extra special: our king was coronated ten years ago this year. In our house it‚Äôs not a big deal, in fact Anja couldn‚Äôt be more of an anti-monarchist if she tried. Lemonade‚Äôs too young to pay it any mind, I‚Äôm sure. But the rest of the country is getting ready.

King‚Äôs Day is full of traditions: young children playing the violin out of tune at the park, tompouce pastries, the king and his family on a heavily-televised trip to a Dutch city that has been preparing for this moment for a year. And forever and for always: people securing a spot on the flea market route days ahead of time.

Today, as I biked across the city, I saw hundreds of them; 40 square feet of pavement taped off by people aiming to use that specific spot to spend their King‚Äôs Day. Peddling by, I thought to myself that it was a rather sweet unwritten rule: I put my name here in a manner that you could erase at any moment, but Dutch custom says you‚Äôre to honor my plan.

I‚Äôm used to people marking these spots ‚Äúbezet‚Äù (‚Äútaken‚Äù) or adding their name for emphasis. Today, however, I noticed many people had made a small figure with their tape, a maker‚Äôs mark of sorts. I‚Äôm learning through Anja‚Äôs ceramics adventure that this is entirely common in the potter community: a small, minimalist figure telling the world you made something.

I hope all those people get what they came for: that specific spot on the pavement, and a fun day to help them Konmari their house. In the meantime, I also hope that the Amsterdamse Bos is quiet on King‚Äôs Day. I‚Äôm looking to take Anja and Lemonade there for a quiet afternoon, far away from the crowds.

  1. I‚Äôm referring to the episode ‚ÄúDe fiets is niets‚Äù (‚Äúthe bike is nothing‚Äù) of the impeccable podcast 99% Invisible by Roman Mars.¬†‚Ü©

Apr 17, 2023

Come back to Chigaco

Spring is here, I think? I spend the afternoon in the park with ex-colleague-turned-friend Susan, who is celebrating landing a new and challenging job. There‚Äôs a boy in the park who‚Äôs walking around barefoot. Later we see him on a slack line. I like this scene; it tells me that summer is almost upon us.

I never seem skilled at enjoying whatever season is here. Instead I‚Äôm forever yearning for what‚Äôs just out of reach. On Javastraat I pass a travel agency, the target audience of which most certainly is concerned with visiting Morocco or Turkey during the summer months. Surprisingly, there‚Äôs a wide array of names that would inspire city trips around the world.

Ever since I passed the agency, Andrew Bird‚Äôs Pulaski at Night has been in my head non-stop. ‚ÄúCome back to Chigaco, city of, city of light.‚Äù

Apr 11, 2023

Meeting Yana and DJ

What I love most about today‚Äôs snapshot is the despair I can see in Lemonade‚Äôs eyes even when her entire body is a background blur. DJ is a calm 12-year-old dog, and Lemonade was thrilled to see another dog in our home for the first time, but her energy level was high enough that I eventually brought her back to her crate. It was right in time, too, because the afternoon light filling the living room made for a nice little portrait.

It was wonderful to welcome Yana into our home for the first time. When I hired her in the late Winter of 2022 as our newest UX designer, I knew there was something special about her. Now, well over a year later, I‚Äôm pleased to call her a friend. We caught up on career adventures, new trends in the design industry, and of course the joys of being a dog mom.

After Yana and DJ left, Anja and I began winding down for the day. After dinner, we watched the latest episode of the final season of Succession, which may have been my favorite one yet. The characters on this show are so complex and candidly-written. I‚Äôm already low-key heartbroken that this show is going to end. At the same time, I‚Äôm also pleased to be alive to watch it unfold in real time.

Apr 10, 2023

The cat

Life sure is different now that we‚Äôve gotten Lemonade on a proper walking schedule. She still feels most comfortable going potty on the puppy pads we have on our balcony, but she absolutely loves going out and exploring the neighborhood.

I‚Äôm surprised by how well she walks on a loose leash, and how few issues we‚Äôve had with the stuff she puts in her mouth. I‚Äôm hoping to make most use of her imprint period, and that means familiarizing her with as many different things as possible.

I‚Äôm happy to find a cat on our morning walk. Lemonade responds to the cat the way I expected a dog would: oozing deference. They stand across from each other for a few minutes, and I reward Lemonade with cheese treats afterwards.

It‚Äôs the first step on the road to Lemonade meeting Pookie, my mother-in-law‚Äôs cat.
